qas.question: When did ITU-R start trying to work towards setting a single international HDTV standard?
What did ITU-R start trying to do in 1983?

answers.text: setting a single international HDTV standard

qas.question: What was one of the issues with setting a single HDTV standard?
What was used as a conversion between the two main frame/field rates?
How many frame/field rates were primarily being used in 1983?
When did ITU-R start trying to work towards setting a single international DVD standard?
What did ITU-R start trying to do in 1981?

plausible_answers.text: suitable frame/field refresh rate, the world already having split into two camps

qas.question: What was one of the issues with setting a single DVD standard?
What was used as a conversion between the three main frame/field rates?
How many frame/field rates were primarily being used in 1981?

context: In <a0_0><b5_0>1983<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the International Telecommunication Union's radio telecommunications sector (ITU-R) set up a <b6_0>working party<b6_0/> (IWP11/6) with the aim of <a1_0>setting a single international HDTV standard<a1_0/>. One of the thornier issues concerned <a2_0>a <b7_0>suitable frame/field refresh rate<a2_0/>, the world already having split into <a4_0><b9_0>two<b9_0/><a4_0/> camps<b7_0/>, 25/50 Hz and 30/60 Hz, largely due to the differences in mains frequency. The IWP11/6 working party considered many views and throughout the 1980s served to encourage development in a number of video digital processing areas, not least conversion between the two main frame/field rates using <a3_0><b8_0>motion vectors<b8_0/><a3_0/>, which led to further developments in other areas. While a comprehensive HDTV standard was not in the end established, agreement on the aspect ratio was achieved.
